questions.text: A 70-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of bad breath and progressive difficulty swallowing solid food. Physical examination shows weight loss. An upper endoscopy is performed, and a photomicrograph of a biopsy specimen obtained from the mid-oesophagus is shown. Which of the following best explains the findings in this patient?

options.label: B
options.text: Atrophy and fibrosis of Esophageal smooth muscle

options.label: D
options.text: The neoplastic proliferation of the squamous epithelium

questions.correct_answer: D. The neoplastic proliferation of the squamous epithelium
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The neoplastic proliferation of the squamous epithelium The neoplastic proliferation of squamous epithelium is the hallmark of squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) of the esophagus , which can manifest with progressive dysphagia and halitosis due to food particles retained in the esophagus. The histopathology involves clusters of keratin pearls destroying normal tissue structure in the upper two-thirds of the esophagus. It typically affects patients with risk factors such as long-term alcohol use, tobacco exposure, achalasia, and diets low in fruits and vegetables.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Well-differentiated neoplastic glandular proliferation is associated with adenocarcinoma of the esophagus , which can manifest with progressive dysphagia and halitosis . A biopsy would, however, not show clusters of keratin pearls but rather high-grade dysplasia of columnar epithelium with adjacent Barrett esophagus . In addition, adenocarcinoma typically involves the lower third rather than the middle of the esophagus. Option: B. Atrophy and fibrosis of the oesophagal smooth muscle can be seen in CREST syndrome or systemic sclerosis . These diagnoses may manifest with dysphagia and halitosis in severe oesophagal However, biopsy findings would not show keratinisation but fibroblast proliferation and smooth muscle atrophy . Moreover, patients with either condition typically present with findings such as sclerodactyly and the Raynaud phenomenon . Option: C. Metaplastic transformation of oesophagal mucosa is seen in Barrett's esophagus , which can manifest with halitosis , as seen in this patient. However, a biopsy would not show the keratin pearls seen here. Instead, it would typically show an extension of the physiologic transformation zone as oesophagal squamous epithelium is replaced with intestinal-type columnar epithelium with goblet cells. Non-dysplastic Barret's oesophagus. The yellow arrow indicates goblet-cell-positive mucosa adjacent to the squamocolumnar junction.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman comes to the physician because of increasing heartburn for the last few months. During this period, she has taken ranitidine several times daily without relief and lost 10kg. She has retrosternal pressure and burning with every meal. She has had heartburn for several years and took ranitidine as needed. She has hypertension. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the last 40 years and drinks one glass of wine occasionally. She appears pale. Her height is 163 cm, her weight is 75 kg, BMI is 27.5 kg/m2. Her temperature is 37.2°C (98.96°F), her pulse is 78/min, and her blood pressure is 136/80 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows mild tenderness to palpation in the epigastric region. Bowel sounds are normal. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which is the most appropriate next step in managing this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Esophagogastroduodenoscopy Increasing retrosternal pain, odynophagia, weight loss in this patient, standing reflux, and a 50-pack year smoking history raise suspicion of Esophageal cancer. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy is the best initial and confirmatory test for suspected oesophagal cancer and can also be used to classify reflux esophagitis and demonstrate a peptic ulcer. It should be conducted in all patients presenting with symptoms of GERD (e.g., retrosternal burning pain, regurgitation) and additional alarm symptoms (e.g., weight loss, anaemia, melena, dysphagia).

Highyeild:

Esophageal cancer The most common type of oesophagal cancer worldwide is squamous cell carcinoma , while in the United States and other Western countries, adenocarcinoma is more common. Esophageal cancer is more commonly found in males than females. The middle third of the esophagus is the most common site for carcinoma. The chemotherapy regimen used for esophageal cancer is Epirubicin, Cisplatin, and 5-FU (ECF) . The most common symptom of esophageal cancer is dysphagia , followed by weight loss . Advanced esophageal cancer can cause choking , coughing , and aspiration from a tracheoesophageal fistula , hoarseness, and vocal cord paralysis from direct invasion into the recurrent laryngeal nerve . The most common sites of metastasis for esophageal cancer are the liver , lungs, and bones .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Twenty-four-hour esophageal pH monitoring is used to confirm the diagnosis in patients with suspected non-erosive reflux disease {Gold standard investigation in GERD }. While this patient presents with retrosternal chest pain and a burning sensation with meals, suggesting acid reflux, the next step in management should rule out a potential malignancy. Option: B. A chest CT scan is helpful to visualise the entire thorax, including the lungs and the mediastinum. Although this patient presents with red flag symptoms of esophageal malignancy, a CT is more appropriate during the staging process after a malignancy has been confirmed. Option: C. An empiric trial of proton-pump inhibitors may be administered if GERD is clinically suspected and there are no indications for further diagnostic testing. Although this patient presents with symptoms of heartburn that may suggest GERD, she also has alarm symptoms. Esophageal cancer must be ruled out first.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man has been noticing progressive difficulty swallowing, first solid food and now liquids. A barium study shows a narrowing just below the carina. Endoscopic biopsy confirms squamous cell carcinoma. Which of the following provides the most accurate information regarding the T stage of an esophageal carcinoma?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Endoscopic ultrasound An endoscopist can identify the depth and length of the tumor, the degree of luminal compromise, the status of regional lymph nodes, and the involvement of adjacent structures. In addition, biopsy samples of the mass and the regional lymph nodes can be obtained. The accuracy of EUS for T staging increases with the depth of invasion.

Endoscopy with biopsy is the investigation of choice for diagnosing esophageal cancer. Endoscopic ultrasoun d is the investigation of choice for staging esophageal cancer, particularly for determining lymph node metastasis's T stage and presence. CECT (computed tomography with contrast) of the abdomen and chest is used to assess the length of the tumor, the thickness of the esophagus and stomach, regional lymph node status, and the presence of metastases to the liver and lungs.

questions.text: Which of the following are curative operations for carcinoma of the oesophagus?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ivor–Lewis operation Ivor Lewis (sometimes called Lewis–Tanner ) operation with an initial laparotomy and construction of a gastric tube, followed by a right thoracotomy to excise the tumor and create an esophagogastric anastomosis. It is done in mid-1/3rd tumours below the aortic arch. The closer this is placed to the apex of the thoracic cavity, the fewer problems there are with reflux disease. Note - Anastomotic leak following Ivor Lewis esophagectomy is a feared complication that in the past was associated with a 50% mortality rate. The anastomosis is intrathoracic, leak cause severe mediastinitis.

His heart rate is 110 bpm, respiratory rate is 18 breaths/min, the temperature is 37.4°C (99.2°F), and oxygen saturation is 93% on room air. His pulmonary examination shows decreased breath sounds at the apices with scattered expiratory wheezes. Blood pressures are equal in both arms. Liver span is not enlarged. There are no palpable abdominal masses. What is the most likely cause of the patient’s presentation?

options.label: C
options.text: Squamous cell carcinoma of the esophagus

questions.correct_answer: C. Squamous cell carcinoma of the esophagus
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Squamous cell carcinoma of the esophagus Esophageal cancer has a high mortality rate as most patients do not present until the advanced disease is present. The typical presenting symptoms of esophageal cancer are dysphagia and significant weight loss . Dysphagia is typically fairly rapidly progressive over weeks to months. Dysphagia initially is only to solid foods but progresses to include semisolids and liquids. Weight loss occurs due to decreased oral intake in addition to cachexia, which is common with cancer. The two major cell types of esophageal cancer are adenocarcinoma and squamous cell carcinoma , which have different risk factors.

Highyeild:

Esophageal cancer is the 8th most common cancer and the 6th most common cause of cancer death worldwide. Squamous cell carcinoma and adenocarcinoma are the most common types of esophageal cancer. The incidence of esophageal cancer is higher in areas of high incidence than in the rest of the world. Aetiological factors vary between the two main types of esophageal cancer. Genetic predisposition may be important in the pathogenesis of esophageal squamous cell cancer. Dietary and environmental factors are essential in developing squamous cell carcinoma. Patients with other aerodigestive malignancies are at particularly high risk. The rise in the incidence of adenocarcinoma coincides with the increase in obesity, GERD, and Barrett’s esophagus in Western populations.

Option B: He has no history of regurgitating food; his dysphagia is progressive and more for solids not seen in Achalasia. Option D: The patient has dysphagia and weight loss, favouring the diagnosis of malignancy more than GERD.

questions.text: Which of the following risk factors is associated with both adenocarcinoma and squamous cell carcinoma of the esophagus?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cigarette smoking Cigarette smoking is associated with both squamous cell carcinoma and adenocarcinoma of esophagus. Various causative factors have been implicated in the development of squamous cell cancers of the esophagus; the etiology of such cancers is primarily related to excess alcohol consumption and cigarette smoking. The relative risk increases with the amount of tobacco smoked or alcohol consumed, with these factors acting synergistically. Squamous cell esophageal carcinoma has also been associated with ingesting nitrates and smoked opiates, as well as mucosal damage caused by such physical insults as long-term exposure to extremely hot tea, the ingestion of lye, radiation-induced strictures, and chronic achalasia. The presence of an esophageal web in association with glossitis and iron deficiency (i.e., Plummer-Vinson or Paterson-Kelly syndrome ) and congenital hyperkeratosis and pitting of the palms and soles have each been linked with squamous cell esophageal cancer, as have dietary deficiencies of molybdenum, zinc, selenium, and vitamin A. Several strong etiologic associations have been observed to account for the development of adenocarcinoma of the esophagus . Such tumours arise in the distal esophagus in association with chronic gastric reflux , often in the presence of Barrett's esophagus . Cigarette smoking is associated with the development of adenocarcinoma of the esophagus .

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A: Barrett's esophagus is associated with Adenocarcinoma , not squamous cell carcinoma. Option B: GERD is associated with Adenocarcinoma , not squamous cell carcinoma. Option D: Lye ingestion is associated with Squamous cell carcinoma and not adenocarcinoma

EUS is the best method to stage cT and paraoesophageal nodes. EUS can distinguish the layers of the oesophageal wall using 12-MHz ultrasound. questions.explanation:
Solution:

Oesophageal candidiasis The above-given images and history point towards esophageal candidiasis, fungal infections are more common than bacterial infections of oesophagitis, and the barium swallow can be easily confused with its esophageal varices because of the filling defect observed. Usually, this patient is immunocompromised by taking steroids or undergoing chemotherapy. Treatment for this is a topical antifungal agent.

GORD is the primary cause of esophageal ulceration, but other factors can contribute, such as: Iatrogenic factors related to endoscopic procedures Presence of a nasogastric tube Certain medications like tetracyclines, potassium chloride tablets, non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, and bisphosphonates Medication lodged in the oesophagus can cause 'kissing' ulcers on opposite sides of the oesophagus Patients may experience odynophagia Infection of the oesophagus is more likely to occur in patients who are immunocompromised, elderly, debilitated or steroid-dependent. Candidiasis is the most common fungal infection characterised by adherent white pseudo-membranes.
